bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 60 (Thursday, April 6, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. GREEN of Tennessee:H.R. 2496.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article One, Section 8, Clause 14The single subject of this legislation is:To provide interim appropriations for the Coast GuardRetired Serviceman's Family Protection and Survivor BenefitsPlans for each fiscal year after fiscal year 2022.[Page H1710]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Appropriations.

summary.text:
Protecting Gold Star Spouses Act of 2023

This bill provides interim appropriations for the Coast Guard Retired Serviceman's Family Protection and Survivor Benefits Plans if a bill providing appropriations for the plans has not been enacted before the fiscal year begins. The bill provides the appropriations at the rate of operations and under the terms and conditions provided by the most recent law making full-year appropriations for the plans.

The appropriations provided by this bill are not available after a bill is enacted that (1) provides appropriations for the plans, or (2) provides appropriations for the Coast Guard without funding the plans.

bill.title: Protecting Gold Star Spouses Act of 2023

item.title: Protecting Gold Star Spouses Act of 2023
Protecting Gold Star Spouses Act of 2023
To provide interim appropriations for the Coast Guard Retired Serviceman's Family Protection and Survivor Benefits Plans for each fiscal year after fiscal year 2022, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Appropriations.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
